title: 113_hr3885
content: The Act is known as the "Generating Real Opportunities for Workers and Transitional Help Act" or the "GROWTH Act." It extends the modified first-tier emergency unemployment compensation. The GROWTH Act extends emergency unemployment compensation, allowing payments until January 1, 2015, for amounts established in an account under section 4002(b) of the Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2008. The GROWTH Act extends emergency unemployment compensation until January 1, 2015, with adjusted percentages and weeks for payments after January 1, 2014. The GROWTH Act extends emergency unemployment compensation until January 1, 2015, with adjusted percentages and weeks for payments after January 1, 2014. The amendments made by this section regarding funding and effective date shall take effect as if included in the enactment of the American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012. SEC. 3. FLEXIBILITY FOR UNEMPLOYMENT PROGRAM AGREEMENTS. This section provides flexibility for states regarding unemployment program agreements, allowing states to enter into subsequent agreements if their previous agreement was terminated, as long as they meet the requirements. Effective December 29, 2013, states that have enacted laws before December 1, 2013, that would violate certain subsections are exempt from those provisions. AUTHORITY TO USE DISCRETIONARY APPROPRIATIONS FOR IN-PERSON REEMPLOYMENT AND UNEMPLOYMENT INSURANCE ELIGIBILITY ASSESSMENTS. The Secretary of Labor can use discretionary appropriations for in-person reemployment and unemployment insurance assessments for beneficiaries from 2014 to 2023, with specific limitations on the amounts for each fiscal year. Additionally, there is a repeal of the medical device excise tax. The medical device excise tax is repealed under Section 5 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, with corresponding amendments to related sections. The effective date for these changes applies to sales after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, Section 6 addresses the approval of the Keystone XL permit. No Presidential permit required for Keystone XL pipeline application filed by TransCanada Keystone Pipeline, L.P. Final environmental impact statement and Nebraska reroute approved by Nebraska governor satisfy all requirements of environmental laws. SEC. 7. Repeal of 30-hour threshold for classification as full-time employee for purposes of the employer mandate in the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act and replacement with 40 hours. The text chunk discusses amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding full-time equivalents and full-time employees for determining applicable large employers under the employer mandate in the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to define a full-time employee as someone who works an average of at least 40 hours per week. These amendments are effective as if included in the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. DISQUALIFICATION ON RECEIPT OF DISABILITY INSURANCE BENEFITS IN A MONTH FOR WHICH UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION IS RECEIVED. The amendment to the Social Security Act states that individuals receiving unemployment compensation are deemed to have engaged in substantial gainful activity for that month. Additionally, the amendment includes definitions of different types of unemployment compensation. The amendment to the Social Security Act deems individuals entitled to unemployment compensation as having rendered services for that month. The amendment includes definitions of various types of unemployment compensation and mandates data matching using electronic means. The effective date for these amendments is after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 9. SOCIAL SECURITY NUMBER REQUIRED FOR CHILD TAX CREDIT REFUND. The amendment requires taxpayers to include their Social Security number on their tax return to claim certain tax benefits. In the case of joint returns, either spouse's Social Security number can fulfill this requirement. The amendment mandates the inclusion of a correct Social Security number or TIN on a tax return to claim specific tax benefits. A conforming amendment is made to section 24 of the Internal Revenue Code. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after the enactment of the Act.
